PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE  
A.  Background and Justification 
1.  The CoR has engaged the state design institute Kostanay Dorproject to carry out the 
detailed engineering design which will be completed in Q4, 2015. It is also recruiting a local 
consultant to prepare the feasibility study in conformance to government requirements. Given 
the difference between ADB and Government in terms of required scope and depth of analysis 
for  project  investment,  additional  due  diligence  is  necessary  for  ADB  financing.  In  this 
connection,  a  PPTA  is  recommended  and  the  PPTA  consultants  will  work  closely  and 
concurrently with CoR consultants to improve the feasibility study and detailed design, hence 
producing mutually agreed design and implementation arrangements suitable for ADB financing. 
The government was advised that approval of the PPTA does not commit ADB to financing any 
ensuing project.

C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement  
3.  The total cost of the TA amounts to $450,000, of which $400,000 will be financed on a 
grant basis by ADB's Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-Others). The Government 
through CoR will provide counterpart support in the form of PIU staff, office space and supplies, 
secretarial assistance, and other in-kind contributions. The value of the government contribution 
is estimated to account for 11% of the total TA cost. The detailed cost estimate is in Table A3.2.

D.  Consulting Services 
4.  The required positions and person-months are indicated in Table A3.3. The PPTA will 
require 12 person-months (PMs) international specialists and 13 PMs of national experts to be 
recruited individually. For project due diligence where feasibility study is under preparation by 
EA following government internal requirements, hiring individual consultants with short duration 
is more appropriate for quick mobilization of consulting service and cost-effective than firms to 
perform the assignment. The individual experts will be engaged by ADB in accordance with the 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time).

5.  The outline terms of reference for the consultants are outlined in the paras below.  
 
6.  Highway Specialist cum Procurement Expert (International, 5 PMs). Qualification:  
Bachelor’s degree or above in civil engineering with at least 20 years’ experience in highway 
planning  and  design,  managing  multidisciplinary  team  and  administering  large  civil  works 
projects; Familiarity with FIDIC and its harmonized MDB version is a prerequisite. Scope of 
duties: Undertake, but not be limited to, the following tasks: (i) conduct due diligence on overall 
project scope, rationale, engineering features including on safety and climate risk mitigation (as 
applicable),  cost  estimates  and  improve  the  detailed  design  and  other  relevant  areas; 
(ii) review past projects of similar size and nature and establish project implementation duration 
and  maintenance  requirements;  (iii)  undertake  project  procurement  risk  assessment  and 
prepare Project Procurement Risk Assessment and Management Plan (P-RAMP), including 
procurement capacity assessment of the EA; (iv) prepare, based on P-RAMP, the capacity 
building program to strengthen EA's capacity in undertaking procurement and address other 
risks identified; (v) prepare draft procurement plan; and (vi) prepare master bidding documents 
for  different  types  of  contracts  under  the  project,  including  an  RFP  for  selection  of 
implementation consultant.  
 
7.  Transport  Economist  (International,  3  PMs).  Qualification:  Bachelor’s  degree  in 
economics or equivalent with broad-based work experience (a minimum of 10 years of relevant 
professional experience) recognized as an expert in transport economics, proven analytical 
skills, and preferably working experience in Kazakhstan or regional countries. Scope of duties: 
Undertake, but not be limited to, the following tasks: (i) review and summarize the project 
economic  rationale,  including  summarizing  and  evaluating  the  project's  economic  risks; 
(ii) review the government feasibility study and macroeconomic and sector contexts, meet with

the  executing  agency  and  other  stakeholders  to  gather  in-depth  information,  and  conduct 
demand analysis and update the traffic forecast; (iii) in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for 
the Economic Analysis of Projects and other relevant publications, identify and compare project 
costs and benefits, assess project sustainability, conduct the economic analysis, sensitivity and 
risk analysis, and identify indicators for project performance monitoring system; (iv) conduct 
assessment of sector particularly road subsector taking into account the problem tree analysis; 
and  (v)  review  areas  for  institutional  strengthening  in  the  context  of  improving  transport 
efficiency and quality of service. 
 
8.  Financial  Specialist  (International,  1  PM).  Qualification:  Bachelor’s  degree  and  a 
broad-based work experience (10 years of relevant professional experience) recognized as an 
expert in transport financial analysis; proven analytical skills and working experience in ADB 
developing member countries, with a recognized accountancy qualification such as a Chartered 
Accountant, Certified Public Accountant or Chartered Certified Accountant. Scope of duties: 
Undertake, but not be limited to, the following tasks: (i) review the government feasibility and 
prepare  the  project  financing  plan;  (ii)  assess  unconstrained  operations  and  maintenance 
requirements for the road network and actual budget allocation over the last 3 or 4 years, and 
carry out the financial analysis and evaluate the financial viability of the investment; (iii) prepare 
an updated financial management assessment; (iv) identify key risks and actions to ensure 
project sustainability and propose related assurances or covenants; and (v) review ongoing and 
planned  institutional  development  and  propose  measures  necessary  for  institutional 
strengthening, particularly in financial management.  
 
9.  Environmental Specialist (International,  1.5 PMs; National 2 PMs). Qualification: 
relevant  education  background  to  undertake  environmental  impact  assessment  works  and 
significant experience for preparing environmental impact assessment for similar projects, and 
be familiar with implementation of Kazakhstan’s environmental protection law; preferably a 
master degree and at least 5 years’ experience in work related with environmental impact 
assessment.  Familiarity  with  the  ADB  Safeguards  Policy  Statement  (SPS)  2009  is  an 
advantage. Scope of duties: undertake, but not be limited to, the following tasks: (i) prepare 
Initial  Environmental  Examination  (IEE)  Report  and  its  Summary  or  Environmental  Impact 
Assessment (EIA) Report and its Summary if it is warranted. The IEE/EIA report should be 
prepared in accordance to the ADB’s  Safeguard Policy Statement  2009 for Environmental 
Assessment Requirement; (ii) conduct meaningful public consultations with affected people; 
(iii) prepare an Environmental Management Plan; (iii) assess the capacity of the Government in 
addressing environmental problems including the institutional arrangements and any capacity 
building measures need to be elaborated, and propose the review procedure for addressing 
environmental concerns of the project, and on this basis, prepare recommendation on how the 
recommendation of IEE or EIA will be implemented; and (iv) Reconfirm the environmental 
classification of the proposed project. 
 
10.  Resettlement  Specialist  (International,  1.5  PMs). Qualification: relevant  education 
background and significant experience in preparing RP and implementing land acquisition and 
resettlement in Central Asia especially for projects in Kazakhstan; full understanding of the ADB 
SPS 2009; preferably a master degree and over 5 years’ experience and at least 3 years’ work 
as resettlement specialist. Scope of duties: undertake, but not be limited to, the following tasks: 
(i) Reconfirm the project classification for Involuntary Resettlement (IR) and Indigenous Peoples 
Safeguards;  (ii)  Prepare  options  to  minimize  land  acquisition  and  associated  impacts;  
(iii) Prepare Resettlement Plan that sets out strategies to mitigate adverse effects and maintain 
living  standards  of  affected  people.  It  shall  address the  policy  objectives  of  ADB  and the 
government for land acquisition and resettlement, in line with the ADB SPS 2009 and relevant 
Government Law and Regulations; (iv) conduct  socio economic survey and 100% census

survey  to  identify  all  persons  who  will  be  displaced  by  the  project  with  appropriate  socio 
economic baseline data and to assess the project's socio economic impact on them, carry out 
meaningful consultations with the affected people; (v) Describe the institutional arrangements 
for addressing social impacts/risks associated with the project to develop grievance redress 
mechanism, and to develop effective arrangement to implement RP; and (vi) Prepare estimated 
budget for implementing RP covering all aspects.  
 
11.  Social Development Specialist (National, 3 PMs). Qualification: relevant education 
background  to  conduct  social  impact  assessment  and  significant  experience  in  preparing 
poverty and social impact assessment. Familiar with ADB’s policy on social impacts especially 
gender and poverty. Preferably master degree with at least 5 years’ related work experience. 
Scope of duties: undertake but will not be limited to the following work: (i) conduct  social impact 
assessment other than social aspects covered by safeguards requirement, especially poverty 
assessment, gender  assessment,  participatory assessment,  labor  impacts  and  other  social 
impacts as described in relevant ADB guideline; (ii) Conduct socio-economic survey to prepare 
Poverty and Social Impact Assessment in compliance with ADB guidelines for social impact 
assessment  other  than  the  social  aspects  covered  by  safeguards  requirement,  especially 
poverty and gender assessment, participatory assessment, labor and  other social impacts, 
specifically to identify social and gender issues in the project's command area and determine 
how the project will impact (both positively and negatively) on the communities' lives, including 
(improvement, if any, in) women's and men's access to markets, municipal services, health, and 
education, livelihood/employment opportunities, and safety, as well as improvement, if any, in 
women's participation in community decision-making; (iii) assess gender issues for the project 
and prepare measures, including gender action plan if warranted; and (iv) prepare a summary 
poverty reduction and social strategy including gender strategy and/or measures as appropriate. 
 
12.  Highway Engineer cum Coordinator (National, 8 PMs). Qualification: an experienced 
road  engineer  with  civil  engineering  degree  qualification  or  above  and  15  years’  related 
experience; have good skills in English language. Scope of duties: undertake, but not be limited 
to, the following tasks: (i) coordinate and facilitate work of all international consultants, including 
on  data  collection,  public  consultations  and  dialogues  with  various  stakeholders,  etc.; 
(ii)  conduct  assessment,  guided  by  international  consultants,  on  road  sector,  costing  and 
engineering aspects of the project; (iii) provide inputs to ADB documents such as the report and 
recommendations to the President, project administration manual, etc.; and (iv) assist ADB fact-
finding and appraisal missions on technical discussions with the EA and Government agencies.  
 
F.   Schedule and Reporting Requirements 
13.  The consulting services will be implemented over a period of 15 months, with estimated 
TA commencement starting on 1 May 2015 and completing on 31 August 2016. TA funds will be 
disbursed in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as 
amended from time to time). The PPTA will be financially closed by 30 November 2016. On a 
regular basis, the consultants will work closely with CoR and its consultants, and provide all 
necessary assistance in the preparation of project documents. The consultant will report directly 
to the project officer.  
 
14.  The consultants will submit to CoR and ADB (i) an interim report within three months of 
commencing services; and (ii) a final report (including a five-page executive summary with key 
findings and recommendations) three weeks after receipt of review comments from CoR and 
ADB. All reports shall be written in English and translated into Russian.
